name: BBC News
notes: UK's state-funded public broadcaster. Aims for impartiality but faces bias accusations from both the left and right. Generally considered a benchmark for centrist, high-quality journalism.

name: The Guardian
notes: UK-based outlet known for its progressive and socially liberal stance. Often focuses on environmental issues, human rights, and is generally critical of conservative politics.

name: The New York Times
notes: A leading US newspaper. Its news reporting aims for objectivity, but its editorial and opinion sections have a clear liberal and progressive orientation.

name: The Wall Street Journal
notes: US-based newspaper with a focus on business and finance. Its news division is generally considered centrist, but its influential editorial page is staunchly conservative.

name: Reuters
notes: Global news agency known for its commitment to neutrality and fact-based reporting. It serves as a source for thousands of other news outlets worldwide.

name: Associated Press (AP)
notes: A US-based global non-profit news agency. Widely regarded as one of the most objective and non-partisan major news sources.

name: CNN
notes: US-based cable news network. While it presents itself as a straight news source, its commentary, choice of stories, and framing are widely considered to have a strong liberal bias.

name: Fox News
notes: US-based cable news network known for its conservative opinion hosts and editorial stance. Highly influential in right-wing politics.

name: Al Jazeera
notes: State-funded broadcaster of Qatar. Provides a global perspective often differing from Western media, but is sometimes criticized for aligning with Qatar's foreign policy interests.

name: The Washington Post
notes: Major US newspaper known for its investigative journalism, particularly on American politics. Its editorial stance is generally liberal.

name: NPR (National Public Radio)
notes: US public radio network. Aims for objective reporting but its audience and some analyses place its overall tone and story selection as leaning slightly to the left.

name: The Times of India
notes: One of India's largest English-language daily newspapers. Generally seen as having a pro-business, establishment-friendly, and moderately nationalist stance.

name: The Hindu
notes: Indian daily newspaper known for its comprehensive coverage and traditionally holding a secular, pro-social justice editorial line. Often critical of the ruling right-wing government.

name: NDTV
notes: Indian television and online news channel. Historically known for a liberal and anti-establishment viewpoint. Recently acquired by the Adani Group, leading to speculation about a potential shift in its editorial stance.

name: The Indian Express
notes: Prominent Indian newspaper known for its strong investigative journalism. Generally considered a centrist paper that often takes a critical but balanced view of the government.

name: Hindustan Times
notes: Major Indian daily newspaper. Generally maintains a centrist position and is considered a mainstream, establishment publication.

name: India Today
notes: Indian news magazine and TV channel. Often perceived as leaning towards the current ruling establishment (BJP), particularly in its television format.

name: The Wire
notes: An independent Indian digital news publication. Known for its strong critical stance towards the government, investigative reports, and left-leaning/liberal commentary.

name: Republic TV
notes: Indian news channel known for its loud, pro-government, and strong nationalist (Hindutva) stance. Highly critical of opposition parties and liberal viewpoints.

name: Zee News
notes: Indian news channel often described as part of the 'Godi Media' for its strong pro-government stance. Its chairman is a BJP-backed Member of Parliament.

name: The Quint
notes: Indian digital news platform that focuses on explanatory and youth-oriented journalism. Generally holds a liberal and progressive perspective.

name: Scroll.in
notes: Indian digital news publication with in-depth reporting and analysis. It is known for being consistently critical of the government from a liberal-left perspective.

name: OpIndia
notes: An Indian right-wing news and opinion website. Known for its strong pro-BJP and Hindutva stance, and has been frequently called out for publishing misinformation and disinformation.

name: Swarajya
notes: Indian magazine and news portal that advocates for market-liberal and right-wing perspectives. It aligns with the cultural and economic policies of the ruling BJP.

name: The Print
notes: Indian digital news platform founded by veteran journalists. It aims to be a non-hyphenated liberal platform and is generally seen as centrist, with a slight tilt towards the establishment.

name: Newslaundry
notes: An independent, subscription-based Indian media watchdog. Known for its critique of the news industry itself and holds a broadly liberal, anti-establishment viewpoint.

name: The Telegraph (India)
notes: Kolkata-based newspaper known for its strong secular, liberal stance and pointedly critical headlines against the central government.

name: Deccan Chronicle
notes: An English-language daily with a strong readership in Southern India. Generally provides centrist coverage of national and regional issues.

name: The News Minute
notes: Independent digital platform focusing on the five southern states. Known for its progressive, gender-sensitive, and independent reporting.

name: The Caravan
notes: A magazine known for long-form, investigative narrative journalism. It is often highly critical of the establishment from a left/liberal perspective.

name: Alt News
notes: A non-profit fact-checking website. Its primary function is verification, not opinion, though it's often perceived as left-leaning due to its focus on debunking right-wing misinformation.

name: Navbharat Times
notes: A major Hindi newspaper from the Times Group. Its editorial stance is pro-business and establishment-friendly, similar to its English counterpart, The Times of India.

name: Punjab Kesari
notes: A major Hindi daily with large circulation in North India. Known for its strong nationalist stance.

name: Mathrubhumi
notes: A major Malayalam-language daily in Kerala, traditionally associated with a secular and social reformist outlook.

name: Sakshi
notes: A major Telugu newspaper founded by a politician. It strongly supports his party, the YSR Congress Party, making its coverage highly partisan.

name: Sakal
notes: A popular Marathi-language daily newspaper. Its ownership has ties to a prominent political family, but its coverage is generally mainstream and centrist.

name: Gujarat Samachar
notes: One of the leading newspapers in the Gujarati language. It maintains a broad, centrist appeal within its regional readership.

name: Dinamalar
notes: A prominent Tamil daily newspaper known for its right-wing, pro-Hindutva, and pro-BJP editorial stance.

name: The Economist
notes: UK-based publication with a focus on global affairs and economics. Advocates for classical liberalism: free markets, free trade, and social liberalism. Can be considered center-right on economics and center-left on social issues.

name: Bloomberg
notes: Financial news company. Its reporting is generally data-driven and centrist, with a slight pro-business, technocratic leaning. Avoids partisan politics in its news coverage.

name: USA Today
notes: A mass-market US newspaper. Its news content is often perceived as centrist, but its editorial stance and framing often align with liberal viewpoints.

name: The Telegraph
notes: A major UK daily newspaper. Traditionally aligned with the Conservative Party (Tories), it is known for its right-leaning, Euroskeptic commentary.

name: The Independent
notes: UK-based online newspaper. It generally holds liberal and pro-Europe stances on most issues.

name: Daily Mail
notes: A highly popular UK tabloid known for its conservative, populist, and often sensationalist content.

name: Le Monde
notes: A leading French daily newspaper. It is generally considered to have a center-left, progressive, and pro-EU editorial stance.

name: Le Figaro
notes: A major French newspaper, and the main competitor to Le Monde. It is traditionally aligned with the French center-right.

name: Der Spiegel
notes: A highly influential German weekly news magazine. Known for its in-depth investigative journalism and a center-left, liberal perspective.

name: Bild
notes: Germany's best-selling tabloid newspaper. Known for its conservative, populist tone and sensationalism.

name: The Globe and Mail
notes: A major Canadian newspaper. Generally considered centrist or slightly center-right, often described as a voice of the Canadian establishment.

name: Toronto Star
notes: A major Canadian newspaper with a long history of advocating for social justice and liberal policies.

name: Asahi Shimbun
notes: A leading Japanese newspaper. Known for its liberal and progressive stance, often critical of conservative governments in Japan.

name: Yomiuri Shimbun
notes: Japanese newspaper with the largest circulation in the world. It has a conservative editorial stance and is generally supportive of the ruling LDP party.

name: China Daily
notes: An English-language daily newspaper owned by the Publicity Department of the Chinese Communist Party. Functions as a propaganda outlet for the Chinese government.

name: People's Daily
notes: The official newspaper of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party. It is the primary mouthpiece of the party.

name: Global Times
notes: A daily tabloid newspaper under the People's Daily. Known for its aggressive, nationalist, and often confrontational editorials targeting Western countries.

name: South China Morning Post
notes: A Hong Kong-based English-language newspaper owned by Alibaba. Aims for comprehensive coverage of China but operates under the constraints of the National Security Law.

name: The Sydney Morning Herald
notes: A major Australian newspaper based in Sydney. Traditionally a centrist paper, it is now generally considered to have a center-left editorial stance.

name: The Australian
notes: A national Australian newspaper owned by News Corp. It is known for its conservative commentary and business-friendly perspective.

name: RT (Russia Today)
notes: A Russian state-controlled international television network. It functions as a propaganda arm of the Russian government, known for spreading disinformation.

name: TASS
notes: A major news agency in Russia, owned and operated by the Russian government. It reflects the official state position on domestic and international affairs.

name: Haaretz
notes: An Israeli newspaper known for its left-wing and liberal stance. It is often highly critical of the Israeli government's policies, particularly regarding the Palestinian territories.

name: The Jerusalem Post
notes: An Israeli English-language newspaper. It generally holds a centrist to right-leaning editorial stance, representing a more mainstream view than Haaretz.

name: Dawn
notes: Pakistan's oldest and most widely read English-language newspaper. Known for its socially liberal and editorially independent stance, often critical of the military establishment.

name: The Times of Israel
notes: An Israeli online newspaper that aims to provide a balanced view of Israel and the region. It is generally considered centrist and less ideologically driven than its peers.

name: Folha de S.Paulo
notes: One of Brazil's most influential newspapers. Known for its pluralistic approach, but often characterized as having a slight center-left or liberal inclination.

name: El Pa√≠s
notes: A leading Spanish daily newspaper. It has a strong pro-European stance and is generally aligned with a center-left, progressive ideology.

name: The Straits Times
notes: An English-language daily broadsheet newspaper based in Singapore. It has a pro-government stance and operates under strict media regulations.

name: Politico
notes: American political journalism company. Known for its in-depth, non-partisan reporting on politics and policy. Focuses on the 'who' and 'why' of politics rather than taking strong ideological stances.

name: The Hill
notes: American news website and newspaper, primarily focused on the U.S. Congress. Known for its balanced reporting and features opinion columns from both sides of the aisle.

name: HuffPost
notes: Originally The Huffington Post, it started as a liberal commentary aggregator and has maintained a strong progressive and left-wing editorial voice.

name: Axios
notes: US news website known for its 'smart brevity' format. Its reporting is generally centrist and fact-based, aiming for efficient, non-partisan delivery of news.

name: WION (World is One News)
notes: An Indian international news channel. Aims to project an Indian perspective on global events. Its stance is generally nationalist and pro-government.

name: Dainik Bhaskar
notes: One of the largest Hindi-language daily newspapers in India. Generally maintains a centrist, mass-market appeal. Known for strong ground reporting.

name: Dainik Jagran
notes: A major Hindi-language daily newspaper with a massive readership. It is widely considered to have a right-wing, pro-BJP editorial stance.

name: Amar Ujala
notes: Another leading Hindi-language daily. It generally takes a centrist to slightly right-leaning stance, often aligning with mainstream nationalist sentiment.

name: Malayala Manorama
notes: A leading Malayalam-language newspaper in Kerala, India. It is generally centrist and has a broad, mainstream appeal, avoiding strong ideological alignment.

name: Ananda Bazar Patrika (ABP)
notes: A prominent Bengali-language newspaper. Traditionally holds a secular and liberal editorial line, often critical of both state and central governments.

name: Eenadu
notes: The largest Telugu-language newspaper. Historically, its founder has been influential in regional politics, and the paper often reflects a pro-business, center-right viewpoint.

name: Daily Thanthi
notes: A leading Tamil-language daily newspaper. It focuses on mass appeal and local issues, generally maintaining a politically neutral or centrist stance.

name: Lokmat
notes: The largest Marathi-language newspaper in India. Its owners have ties to the Congress party, but the paper itself maintains a broad, centrist editorial stance.

name: The Economic Times
notes: India's leading business newspaper. Like most financial papers, its focus is pro-business, pro-market, and fiscally conservative.

name: Business Standard
notes: An Indian daily business newspaper. Known for its high-quality, credible reporting and commentary, it is considered more editorially centrist and sober than its competitors.

name: Livemint
notes: An Indian business newspaper from the same house as Hindustan Times. It has a modern, digital-first approach and a pro-market editorial stance.

name: Firstpost
notes: An Indian digital news portal, part of the Network18 group. It has a distinctly right-wing, pro-government orientation.

name: Deccan Herald
notes: An English-language daily newspaper from Karnataka, India. Known for its balanced coverage and generally centrist, moderate editorial positions.

name: The Tribune
notes: A major Indian English-language daily newspaper based in Chandigarh. It is widely respected for its sober tone and centrist, independent editorial stance.

name: The New Indian Express
notes: An Indian English-language newspaper with a distinct and vocal right-wing, nationalist editorial stance. Not to be confused with The Indian Express.

name: Breitbart News
notes: An American news and opinion website known for its populist, nationalist, and highly partisan right-wing content. Often accused of publishing conspiracy theories.

name: The Daily Wire
notes: A conservative American news and opinion website founded by Ben Shapiro. Known for its strong conservative commentary and opposition to progressive politics.

name: MSNBC
notes: An American cable news channel and website. Known for its progressive and left-wing opinion hosts and serves as a counterpart to Fox News's conservative programming.

name: CBS News
notes: The news division of the American television network CBS. Generally considered to be slightly left-of-center in its story selection and framing.

name: ABC News
notes: The news division of the American television network ABC. Similar to CBS, it's considered a mainstream media outlet that leans slightly to the left.

name: The Sun
notes: A major UK tabloid newspaper. Known for its populist, conservative, and strongly pro-Brexit stance. Owned by News Corp.

name: Financial Times
notes: UK-based international business newspaper. It supports free markets but is socially liberal. Its editorial stance is generally centrist and pro-globalization.

name: Nikkei Asia
notes: The flagship English-language publication of Nikkei, Inc., Japan's largest media company. Focuses on Asian business and has a pro-market, center-right perspective.

name: Kyodo News
notes: A non-profit cooperative news agency based in Tokyo, Japan. It is the Japanese equivalent of the Associated Press, aiming for neutral, objective reporting.

name: Corriere della Sera
notes: A leading Italian daily newspaper. It is generally considered a moderate, centrist, and establishment newspaper.

name: Deutsche Welle (DW)
notes: Germany's public international broadcaster. Similar to the BBC World Service, it aims for objective, balanced reporting with a focus on German and European perspectives.

name: The Moscow Times
notes: An independent English-language online newspaper based in Amsterdam. It is known for its critical coverage of the Russian government.

name: The Intercept
notes: An American news organization known for its adversarial, investigative journalism. It has a strong left-wing perspective and is often critical of US foreign policy and corporate power.

name: Vice News
notes: The news division of Vice Media. Known for its immersive, documentary-style reporting on under-covered topics, with a clear youth-oriented, progressive, and left-wing perspective.

name: The Daily Beast
notes: An American news and opinion website with a focus on politics and pop culture. It has a tabloid-style energy and a strong liberal to left-wing bias.

name: Sputnik News
notes: A Russian state-owned news agency, radio broadcaster, and website. It is widely regarded as a propaganda and disinformation outlet for the Russian government.

name: Xinhua News Agency
notes: The official state-run press agency of the People's Republic of China. It is the main channel for the distribution of news and propaganda by the Chinese government.

name: The Korea Herald
notes: South Korea's largest English-language daily newspaper. It provides mainstream, generally centrist coverage of events in the Korean peninsula.

name: The Jakarta Post
notes: An English-language daily newspaper in Indonesia. It has a reputation for being a liberal, independent voice in the region.

name: The Irish Times
notes: An Irish daily broadsheet newspaper. Generally considered a liberal and progressive newspaper of record in Ireland.
